facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1564 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Petition No. 378 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CiviL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1564 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Petition No. 378 of 1962. N. Dikshit, S. P. Nayar for R. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: A plot of land bearing S. No. NA-29-A of Juhu, Bombay, was requisitioned on May 2, 1942 for the purposes of the Union of India under r. 75-A of the Defence of India Rules for military purposes.

anchor.surface_text: On May 2. 1942 a plot of land bearing S. No. NA-29-A of Juhu, Bombay, was requisitioned for the purposes of the Union of India under r. 75-A 1  of the Defence of India Rules for military purposes. It is companymon case that this plot of land was acquired for the companystruction of a road leading to a military aerodrome at Juhu during the last war.

facts.text: The plot of land was acquired for the construction of a road leading to a military aerodrome at Juhu during the last war.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that this plot of land was acquired for the companystruction of a road leading to a military aerodrome at Juhu during the last war. The land originally belonged to the husband of the first respondent who claims to have succeeded to it by virtue of a will.

facts.text: The land originally belonged to the husband of the first respondent who succeeded to it by virtue of a will.

anchor.surface_text: The land originally belonged to the husband of the first respondent who claims to have succeeded to it by virtue of a will. The owner of the plot was receiving companypensation for the requisition until December 29, 1952 when a numberification was issued under s. 7 1  of the Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act enacted on March 14, 1952, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: The owner received compensation for the requisition until December 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The owner of the plot was receiving companypensation for the requisition until December 29, 1952 when a numberification was issued under s. 7 1  of the Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act enacted on March 14, 1952, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: A notification was issued under s. 7(1) of the Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952 on December 29, 1952, acquiring the land by the Government of India, Ministry of Works, Housing and Supply, vesting it in the Government from the date of the notification.

anchor.surface_text: when a numberification was issued under s. 7 1  of the Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act enacted on March 14, 1952, hereinafter referred to as the Act. The numberification was to the effect that the land was being acquired I by the Government of India, Ministry of Works, Housing and Supply, that it would vest in the Government from the date of the numberification and there was a declaration of vesting in the numberification itself.

facts.text: The second respondent, the Collector of Bombay, offered compensation at the rate of Rs. 11 per sq. yard on February 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The second res- pondent, hereinafter referred to as the Collector of Bombay, offered companypensation at the rate of Rs. 11 per sq. yard on February 20, 1961. The petitioner, the first respondent herein, claimed at the rate of Rs. 100 per sq. yard plus the usual 15 solatium for companypulsory acquisition.

facts.text: The petitioner (first respondent herein) claimed compensation at Rs. 100 per sq. yard plus 15% solatium.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, the first respondent herein, claimed at the rate of Rs. 100 per sq. yard plus the usual 15 solatium for companypulsory acquisition. In the absence of an agreement between the parties, the Chief Judge, Court of Small Causes, Bombay, was appointed as arbitrator under s. 8 of the Act.

facts.text: Chief Judge, Court of Small Causes, Bombay, was appointed as arbitrator under s. 8 of the Act due to absence of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of an agreement between the parties, the Chief Judge, Court of Small Causes, Bombay, was appointed as arbitrator under s. 8 of the Act. The arbitrator gave numberice to the petitioner to put in her claim and also to the Government of India to put in its statement of valuation.

facts.text: Before the arbitrator, petitioner claimed Rs. 75 per sq. yard plus 15% solatium, while the State offered Rs. 11 per sq. yard without solatium.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claimed companypensation at the rate of Rs. 75 per sq. yard plus 15 solatium for companypulsory acquisition while the offer of the State was only Rs. 11 per sq. yard without any solatium.

facts.text: First respondent preferred a petition in Bombay High Court on September 18, 1962 challenging provisions of s. 8(3) of the Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court declared cl. b of sub-s. 3 of s. 8 of the Act, including 'whichever is less', ultra vires Art. 31(2) on August 7, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived the companytentions put forward oil behalf of the Union of India and allowed the petition holding that cl.  b  including the words whichever is less of sub-s.  3  of s. 8 of the Act was ultra vires Art. 31 of the Constitution and as such void.

facts.text: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952 (Act 30 of 1952) enacted on March 14, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) granted by Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Bombay against the judgment of that companyrt dated August 7, 1964 in Miscellaneous Petition No. 378 of 1962 declaring cl.  b  of sub-s.  3  of S. 8 of the Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952  Act 30 of 1952  including the words whichever is less ultra vires Art. 31 2  of the Constitution and as such void.

anchor.surface_text: From the language used in s. 8, learned companynsel for the ap- pellant Wanted to draw the inference that the expression have regard to only meant that the arbitrator was to keep the matters referred to in mind or be companyscious of the same but that he was number companypelled to guide himself thereby.

arguments.claim: Twice requisition date value bears no relation to acquisition value; arbitrary due to post-war price spiral

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon knowledge that all over India there has been a spiralling of land prices after the companyclusion of the last world war although the inflation has been greater in urban areas,

holdings.text: the mode prescribed in cl. b must be held to be arbitrary. It has no relation to the value of the land at the date of the notice under s. 7 which may be many years after the date of requisition.

anchor.surface_text: No exception is taken to the mode prescribed in cl. a of sub-s. 3 but the mode prescribed in cl. b must be held to be arbitrary. It has no relation to the value of the land at the date of the notice under s. 7 which may be many years after the date of requisition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. (b) uses requisition date value unrelated to acquisition; long gap (1942 requisition, 1953 acquisition) without justification; follows precedents on arbitrary anterior dates.

holdings.text: The words of sub-s. 3 are mandatory and compel the arbitrator to accept only the smaller figure arrived at after assessment on the two modes of valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The words of sub-s. 3 are mandatory and compel the arbitrator to accept only the smaller figure arrived at after assessment on the two modes of valuation. No exception is taken to the mode prescribed in cl. a of sub-s. 3 but the mode prescribed in cl. b must be held to be arbitrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-s. (3) language leaves no choice; arbitrator rigidly bound to lesser amount; rejects directory interpretation of 'have regard to'.

holdings.text: The expression have regard to in sub-cl. e of sub-s. 1 of s. 8 therefore does not give the arbitrator any freedom of considering the two modes laid down in sub-s. 3 and accepting the one which he thought fair. The first point about the opening portion of cl. e being mandatory and the latter portion being directory cannot therefore be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of sub-s. 3 of s. 8 leaves the arbitrator no choice of assessing the value in terms of cl. a even if he was of opinion that the mode fixed thereunder afforded a just equivalent of the property to its owner. He had to make his assessment in terms of cl. b . The expression have regard to in sub-cl. e of sub-s. 1 of s. 8 therefore does not give the arbitrator any freedom of considering the two modes laid down in sub-s. 3 and accepting the one which he thought fair. The first point about the opening portion of cl. e being mandatory and the latter portion being directory cannot therefore be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase requires strict adherence; ss.(2) irrelevant to acquisition value; no discretion to choose higher fair value.

holdings.text: We cannot therefore accept the proposition that the impugned clause satisfies the requirements of Art. 31 2 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. (b) ignores excess over twice requisition value like Bela Banerjee ceiling; denies just equivalent; no rational principle; appellant failed to justify.

holdings.text: it was for the State to show that fixation of compensation at the market value of an anterior date does not amount to violation of the constitutional guarantee. This, in our opinion, the appellant has signally failed to do.

anchor.surface_text: There this Court observed that the fixing of an anterior date for arriving it the market value of the land did not ipso facto invalidate the acquisition, but that there might be circumstances which would justify such a fixation and it was there pointed out that it was for the State to show that fixation of compensation at the market value of an anterior date does not amount to violation of the constitutional guarantee. This. in our opinion, the appellant has signally failed to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Namasivaya, state bears burden to justify anterior date; no circumstances or grounds shown here.

holdings.text: In appeal we do not feel disposed to take a different view. If the High Court had any discretion in the matter-and it is not suggested that it had none-the exercise of such discretion ought not to be over-ruled by us Unless we are satisfied that the High Court had acted on some wrong principle or committed some error of law or failed to consider matters which demand consideration.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay from arbitrator appointment (1961) to petition (1962) not excessive; no bar to fundamental rights relief; High Court properly condoned.

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Mrs. Bela Banerjee and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of West Bengal v. Mrs. Bela Banerjee and others 1  the Court examined the question as to what companypensation for property acquired meant under Art. 31 2  of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Mrs Bela Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Under Art. 31(2) compensation means just equivalent of the property deprived of; principles must ensure full indemnification; fixing anterior date for value arbitrary if unrelated to acquisition
precedents.cited_holding: While it is true that the legislature is given the discretionary power of laying down the principles which should govern the determination of the amount to be given to the owner for the property appropriated, such principles must ensure that what is determined as payable must be companypensation, that is, a just equivalent of what the owner has been deprived of.

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 1  the provi- sion as to companypensation for companypulsory acquisition of land under Madras Lignite  Acquisition of Land  Act, 1953 came up for companysideration by this Court.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v D Namasivaya Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: Fixation of compensation on market value of anterior date unrelated to acquisition date is arbitrary and violates Art. 31(2)
precedents.cited_holding: Fixation of companypensation for companypulsory acquisition of lands numberified many years after that date, on the market value prevailing on the date on which lignite was discovered is wholly arbitrary and inconsistent with the letter and spirit of Art. 31 2

precedents.citation: Vajravelu Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector 1

anchor.surface_text: Vajravelu Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector 1  it was said at p. 625 It may, therefore, be taken as settled law that under Art. 31 2  of the Constitution before the Constitution  Fourth Amendment  Act, 1955,

precedents.case_name: Vajravelu Mudaliar v Special Deputy Collector
precedents.cited_proposition: Under Art. 31(2) before Fourth Amendment, acquired person entitled to just equivalent of land deprived
precedents.cited_holding: It may, therefore, be taken as settled law that under Art. 31 2  of the Constitution before the Constitution  Fourth Amendment  Act, 1955, a person whose land was acquired was entitled to companypensation i.e. a just equivalent of the land of which he was deprived.

precedents.citation: N. B. Jeejeebhoy v. Assistant Collector

anchor.surface_text: N. B. Jeejeebhoy v. Assistant Collector -  the requisite numberification under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was issued in May 1948 and that under s. 6 in August 1949,

precedents.cited_proposition: Principles from Bela Banerjee case restated: compensation means just equivalent; anterior date fixation arbitrary without reason
precedents.cited_holding: Bela Banerjees case 1  laid down the following principles  1  The expression companypensation in Art. 31 2  of the Constitution meant just equivalent of what the owner has been deprived of  2  The principles laid down by the legislature shall be only for the determination of the companypensation so defined

precedents.citation: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zemindar of Parlakimedi 2

anchor.surface_text: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zemindar of Parlakimedi 2  There it was observed by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council that the expression have regard to or expressions very close to this were scattered throughout this Act,

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of sub-s. 3 of s. 8 leaves the arbitrator no choice of assessing the value in terms of cl. a even if he was of opinion that the mode fixed thereunder afforded a just equivalent of the property to its owner. He had to make his assessment in terms of cl. b . The expression have regard to in sub-cl. e of sub-s. 1 of s. 8 therefore does not give the arbitrator any freedom of considering the two modes laid down in sub-s. 3 and accepting the one which he thought fair. The first point about the opening portion of cl. e being mandatory and the latter portion being directory cannot therefore be accepted.

Clause b of sub-s. 3 of s. 8 leaves the arbitrator no choice of assessing the value in terms of cl. a even if he was of opinion that the mode fixed thereunder afforded a just equivalent of the property to its owner. He had to make his assessment in terms of cl. b . The expression have regard to in sub-cl. e of sub-s. 1 of s. 8 therefore does not give the arbitrator any freedom of considering the two modes laid down in sub-s. 3 and accepting the one which he thought fair. The first point about the opening portion of cl. e being mandatory and the latter portion being directory cannot therefore be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: There this Court observed that the fixing of an anterior date for arriving it the market value of the land did not ipso facto invalidate the acquisition, but that there might be circumstances which would justify such a fixation and it was there pointed out that it was for the State to show that fixation of compensation at the market value of an anterior date does not amount to violation of the constitutional guarantee. This. in our opinion, the appellant has signally failed to do.
